Instituto Medicina Tropical, Sao Paulo and the @CaddeProject have just genome sequenced the first South American case of #COVID19 within 2 days of diagnosing the patient. @NetworkArtic protocol. More interestingly, this is the first genome from the huge Italian outbreak.

Which suggests some coronavirus sequence has been obtained but it is not similar to SARS-cov and if it is just in one patient is probably just residual viral RNA from some other coronavirus.

Google translate says ‚ÄúFrom the test results obtained so far, ‚Ä¶, but it is really very inclined not to be SARS coronavirus. The homology is very low, with less than 4% gene coverage, making it impossible to judge. Need to test again.‚Äù https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=zh-CN&u=https://k.sina.com.cn/article_1315590387_4e6a50f301900p0k6.html&prev=search¬†‚Ä¶

In one way or another I think that must be true. I guess the labs are doing metagenomic sequencing and a fragment of some coronavirus came up (which means little). ‚ÄôSARS‚Äô may be being used in some reports as synonymous with (any) coronavirus.

I guess that means 4% of a coronavirus genome in a patient - you‚Äôd probably find that in a lot of people. Still 4% of coronavirus genome is > 1kb and would be possible to rule out known coronaviruses.

Obviously they need to get this right and be certain it is not an error but finding a new coronavirus in a patient that you had _a priori_ identified as part of a cluster is unlikely not to be important.

A new coronavirus apparently. So my immediate thoughts are that this must be exposure to live animals (probably mammals) in an urban environment. https://twitter.com/greg_folkers/status/1214893479165227008¬†‚Ä¶

The Wuhan-associated novel coronavirus genome has been released on Genbank with annotations. Originally submitted 5th January and has been updated yesterday. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/MN908947.2¬†‚Ä¶
Some phylogenetic trees of the new coronavirus from Wuhan have been posted to GISAID by . You will need a GISAID login to see them (I am not sure why they are not just posted on an open website).
